newsitem.title: SINGAPORE: Singapore shares open firmer on speculative stocks.
newsitem.headline: Singapore shares open firmer on speculative stocks.

text.p: Brisk trading in speculative stocks pushed Singapore shares firmer on Wednesday.
"It's the return of the SESDAQ speculative stocks. I doubt the trading activity is sustainable. Profit-taking is bound to set in sooner or later," said a dealer with a local brokerage.

Dealers said they expected bargain hunting in oversold blue chips on Wednesday, encouraged by positive sentiment stemming from Singapore's 6.4 percent non-oil domestic export growth in July and unchanged U.S. interest rates.
The 30-share Straits Times Industrials Index rose 14.51 points to 2,138.32 at 0221 GMT.
Market volume was 41.9 million shares with advances swamping decliners by 162 to 76.

Transmarco shares resumed trading and climbed steeply to a morning high of Singapore $11.90 (US$8.44) and was at S$10.70, up by S$0.90 at 0218 GMT. It was boosted by news that Indonesian Putera Sampoerna, through Miel Investment Corp, had increased his takeover bid to Singapore $8.55 per share.
Lindeteves-Jacoberg hit a high of $0.84, up S$0.015, on a turnover of 2.62 million shares. It saw a block deal of 500,000 units done at S$0.813 in early morning.
